column1: Skeletal muscles contract through a complex process involving myofibrils
Myofibrils are composed of repeating units called sarcomeres
Each sarcomere contains thin filaments of actin and thick filaments of myosin
The contraction begins when the nervous system sends an electrical signal to the muscle
This signal triggers the release of calcium ions into the sarcoplasm
Calcium binds to troponin, a protein associated with the thin filaments
This binding changes the shape of tropomyosin, exposing the binding sites on actin
Myosin heads, which are attached to the thick filaments, attach to the exposed actin binding sites
The myosin heads then undergo a power stroke, pulling the actin filaments towards the center of the sarcomere
This sliding of filaments shortens the sarcomere, leading to muscle contraction
The contraction ceases when calcium is actively pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, detaching myosin from actin
The filaments return to their original positions, lengthening the sarcomere and relaxing the muscle
This cycle of contraction and relaxation is how skeletal muscles perform their functions
The molecular mechanisms of myofibril contraction in skeletal muscles involve a series of precise interactions between actin, myosin, calcium ions, and regulatory proteins
